entry.et: Middle English moder, from Old English mōdor; akin to Old High German muoter mother, Latin mater, Greek mētēr, Sanskrit mātṛ

def.dt: :a female parent
:a woman in authority
:the superior of a religious community of women
:an old or elderly woman
:source origin necessity is the mother of invention
:maternal tenderness or affection
:motherfucker
:something that is an extreme or ultimate example of its kind especially in terms of scale the mother of all construction projects
:of, relating to, or being a mother
:bearing the relation of a mother
:derived from or as if from one's mother
:acting as or providing parental stock used without reference to sex
:to give birth to
:to give rise to :produce
:to care for or protect like a mother

entry.et: archaic mother dregs, lees; akin to Middle Dutch moeder dregs

def.dt: :mother of vinegar
:storm petrel
:a cell that gives rise to other cells usually of a different sort
:the country from which the people of a colony or former colony derive their origin
:the country of one's parents or ancestors
:fatherland
:a country that is the origin of something
:the legendary author of a collection of nursery rhymes first published in London about 1760
:a person who assumes an overly protective maternal attitude

entry.et: probably from Mother Hubbard, character in a nursery rhyme

def.dt: :a loose usually shapeless dress
